occurrences.line_text: Rusht fiercely forth, the battell to renew,
Could stand on foot, now to renew the fight.
Then gan he all this storie to renew,
So all afresh gan former fight renew.
She gan afresh thus to renew her wretched case.
Comaunded them their daily workes renew,
And gan renew her former cruelnesse:
They turne afresh, and oft renew their former threat.
Kindling a fresh, gan battell to renew,
And euer bad him stay, till time the tide renewd.
Who maistring them, renewd his former heat;
And home returne, where all should be renewd
Renew'd her death by timely death denying:
Then gan this Realme renewe her passed prime:
She fed her wound with fresh renewed bale;
He, now to proue his late renewed might,
Till she to him her gratious speach renewed;
But toward th'end Sir Arthegall renewed
Breeder of new, renewer of old smarts:
Peepes foorth, and soone renewes her natiue pride;
From needlesse trouble of renewing fight
Till Romulus renewing it, to Rome remoud.
Whereat renfierst with wrath and sharpe regret,
Oft he re'nforst, and oft his forces fayld,
And twise renforst, backe to their ships to fly,
Yet if thou wilt renounce thy miscreaunce,
That his good steed, all were he much renound
The Lord of Many Ilands, farre renound
Yet shortly he renounst the vassalage
Endlesse renowm, that more then death is to be sought.
Renowmd throughout the world for sacred lore,
And thenceforth were renowmd, & sought from place to place.
Is farre renowmd through many bold emprize;
The Gardin of Adonis, farre renowmd by fame.
Sir Paris far renowmd through noble fame,
And Inachus renowmd aboue the rest;
Riches, renowme, and principality,
With high renowme, and great felicitie?
So may ye gaine to you full great renowme,
Of passing valew, and of great renowme,
That him did much renowme, and far his fame display.
At last forth comes that far renowmed Queene,
Goe to then, O thou farre renowmed sonne
Such one it was, as that renowmed Snake
That shall ye euermore renowmed make,
For to demaund of his renowmed guest:
Pyrrhochles is his name, renowmed farre
And is for Venus loues renowmed more,
Throughout the world renowmed far and neare,
From this renowmed Prince deriued arre,
And both of them men of renowmed might;
But Elfant was of most renowmed fame,
To hunt for glorie and renowmed praise;
Renowmed kings, and sacred Emperours,
And for his warlike feates renowmed is,
Renowmed Martia, and redoubted Emmilen.
Faire Lincolne, both renowmed far away,
As that renowmed Poet them compyled,
Ne more renowmed for their cheualrie,
What time the fame of this renowmed prise
And farre renowmed through exceeding fame;
Tybris, renowmed for the Romaines fame,
And there the three renowmed brethren were,
Lauding and praysing his renowmed worth,
Well knowne, and far renowmed heretofore,
That shall you most renowmed make for euermore.
Renowmed much in armes and derring doe:
Through famous Poets verse each where renownd,
Order of Maydenhead, the most renownd,
And eke that ample Pit, yet farre renownd,
That seem'd the spoile of some right well renownd.
And whom I lust, do heape with glory and renowne?
With Gonorill, long had in great renowne,
They three be dead with shame, the Squire liues with renowne.
He liues, but takes small ioy of his renowne;
That is a mayden Queene of high renowne,
With his rude clawes the wicket open rent,
Who streight him rent in thousand peeces small,
For that Hippolytus rent corse he did redresse.
And almost rent her tender hart in tway;
Both loftie towres and highest trees hath rent,
The mightie trunck halfe rent, with ragged rift
Which shaking off, he rent that yron dore,
Her looser golden lockes he rudely rent,
With garments rent, and haire discheueled,
Her golden lockes most cruelly she rent,
That seemd her tender heart was rent in twaine,
As budding braunch rent from the natiue tree,
And smot, and bit, and kickt, and scratcht, and rent,
The sacred Diademe in peeces rent,
Would him haue rent in thousand peeces strayt:
His cursed life out of her lodge haue rent:
Thenceforth this Realme was into factions rent,
Beautie, and money, they that Bulwarke sorely rent.
They on this rock are rent, and sunck in helplesse wawes.
By these rent reliques, speaking their ill plights?
The which may bring my ship, ere it be rent,
Tho gan she gather vp her garments rent,
His rugged flesh, and rent his ragged heare:
That of that feend was rent without remorse:
Himselfe in thousand peeces fondly rent,
Their swerds & speres were broke, & hauberques rent;
And from her head oft rent her snarled heare:
There were rent robes, and broken scepters plast,
Their girlonds rent, their bowres despoyled all;
As if their soules they would attonce haue rent
For to haue rent his shield and armes away,
Rude was his garment, and to rags all rent,
With briers and bushes all to rent and scratcht;
And rent his haire and scratcht his face for paine.
That made the rockes to roare, as they were rent.
With locks all loose, and rayment all to rent;
Torne all to rags, and rent with many a wound,
So was this Souldan rapt and all to rent,
Doe all attonce their thunders rage forth rent,
Them fouly rent, and shamefully defaced had.
That through the yron walles their way they rent,
Gan teare her hayre, and all her garments rent,
Him rudely rent, and all to peeces tore:
As if he would in peeces him haue rent;
Rent by the root; which he so sternely shooke,
As if they would haue rent the brasen skies.
Which they from many long had robd and rent,
Rent vp her brest, and bosome open layd,
As if he would haue rent him with his cruell clawes.
And oft refreshed, battell oft renue:
And to renue the rigour of his smart:
Whose shield he beares renuerst, the more to heape disdayn.
Then from him reft his shield, and it renuerst,
And them repaide againe with double more.
To Morpheus house doth hastily repaire.
But that good knight would not so nigh repaire,
Vnto those natiue woods for to repaire,
Flesh may empaire (quoth he) but reason can repaire.
To rest them selues, and weary powres repaire,
And their forwasted kingdome to repaire:
So well he did her deadly wounds repaire,
Into her lodging to repaire a while,
Another did the dying bronds repaire
Or Ida, where the Gods lou'd to repaire,
That euery knight, which doth this way repaire,
A knight that way there chaunced to repaire;
And with a remnant did to sea repaire,
Of louers loosely knit, where list them to repaire.
Withouten dread of perill to repaire
To which when he according did repaire,
All which he vndertooke for to repaire,
How Fortune will your ruin'd name repaire,
He ere he could his weapon backe repaire,
So shall you soone repaire your present euill plight.
Till she repaired haue her tackles spent,
That there mote be no hope of reparation,
And dreames, gan now to take more sound repast,
With dew repast they had recured well,
And bodies were refresht with due repast,
His mind was full of spirituall repast,
Ne man nor beast may rest, or take repast,
Now well recouered after long repast,
There leaue we them in pleasure and repast,
For beasts and foules to feede vpon for their repast.
For life must life, and bloud must bloud repay.
Ye will me now with like good turne repay,
That curt'sie with like kindnesse to repay;
And tribute backe repay as to their King.
That thankfull guerdon may to you repay.
What may suffise, to be for meede repayd
By equall dome repayd on his owne pate:
Her selfe most gratefull shew'd, & heaped thanks repayd.
But all is now repayd with interest againe.
But with their owne repayed duely weare,
Tho to his daughter Rigan he repayrd,
To which they all repayr'd, both most and least,
Into her fathers closet to repayre;
To snaky-locke Medusa to repayre,
And dayly yet thou doest the same repayre:
Which daily may to thy sweete lookes repayre,
The liberty of women did repeale,
And all forepast displeasures to repeale.
My leasure, so long leaues here to repeat:
He did them aske, who all that passed gan repeat.
To her, whose name he often did repeat;
And eke all Cupids warres they did repeate,
Then preacing to the pillour I repeated
To ioyne your force, their forces to repell,
Whereas they readie found them to repell,
That maugre all their might, he did repell,
Prince Arthur them repelles, and fowle
And often knockt his brest, as one that did repent.
His cruell facts he often would repent;
Now praysd, hereafter deare thou shalt repent:
Whose chaunce it was, that soone he did repent,
Which her ador'd, may sore repent with me,
I sweare, ere long shall dearely it repent;
The sonne of Climene he did repent,
Reproch the first, Shame next, Repent behind:
And made repent, that he had rashly lusted
Yet will I neuer of my loue repent,
Gan to repent, that she had beene so mad,
Who shortly must repent that now so vainely brauest.
His former fancies ruth he gan repent,
And for what cause declare, so mote ye not repent?
Vile cowheard dogge, now doe I much repent,
And late repentance, which shall long abyde.
Where he is taught repentance, and
And sad Repentance vsed to embay
And trew Repentance they to Vna brought:
Behinde him was Reproch, Repentance, Shame;
Repentance feeble, sorrowfull, and lame:
Shame lowrd, Repentance sigh'd, Reproch did scould;
Reproch sharpe stings, Repentance whips entwind,
Do breede repentaunce late, and lasting infamie.
I put repentaunce for things past and gon.
Then that thou hadst repented it too late?
Deserues to tast his follies fruit, repented payne.
That she repented sore, to haue him angered.
Fell into wretched woes, which she repented late.
As her repenting so to haue missayd,
Art, and that Art at nature did repine;
But Lachesis thereat gan to repine,
And sternly gan repine at his beheast;
Whence soone vpstarting much he gan repine,
Of seruile yoke, that nobler harts repine.
Yet greatly did the Beast repine at those
Repined greatly, and did him miscall,
Does seeke to perce: repining courage yields
Henceforth his ghost freed from repining strife,
STANZAS IN 1590 REPLACED IN 1596 WITH OTHERS.
And these weake impes replanted by thy might;
Into the world, it to replenish more;
Which still she bore, replete with magick artes;
It to repleuie, and my sonne repriue:
The gentle knight; who nought to him replide,
And thus replide, How euer, Sir, ye file
But she was more engrieued, and replide;
But by a Tyrannesse (he then replide,)
Then thus replide; Now sure and by my life,
What is that Blattant Beast? (then he replide)
And thus replide; Faire chyld, the high desire
To whom the Prince thus goodly well replied;
Good or bad (gan his brother fierce reply)
Pyrrochles gan reply the second time,
Ne lenger stayd for th'other to reply,
But what so stonie mind (she then replyde)
Wherewith all full of wrath, she thus replyde;
He thus replyde; Now surely syre, I find,
To proue the wide report of her great Maiestee.
That sent to heauen the ecchoed report
That home ye may report thrise happie newes;
Now when report of that their perilous paine,
His learned daughters would to me report,
And fierce of force, was dreadfull to report:
As th'Isle of Delos whylome men report
In shame of knighthood, as I largely can report.
Or speake ye of report, or did ye see
That their report did farre away rebound,
That still are led with euery light report.
Whilome it was (as Faeries wont report)
I heard report that farre abrode did fly,
Great weaknesse, and report of him much ill,
To hearke what any one did good report,
That of their loues successe they there may make report.
Of courtly fauour, fed with light report,
Were yrkesome to report; yet that foule Beast
At last yledd with farre reported praise,
To see her Lord, that was reported drent,
All night afflict thy naturall repose,
So forth she rode without repose or rest,
Her counsell, if he should her trust in me repose.
His glory did repose, and credit did maintaine.
Homeward to march, themselues there to repose,
Where better seem'd he mote himselfe repose;
There did the warlike Maide her selfe repose,
I may here with your selfe some small repose obtaine.
Vnto this place, and therein to repose
A piteous spectacle did represent,
To thee shall represent. He from the head
Then beautie, which was made to represent
For that same Crocodile doth represent
And said, Deare sonne, thy causelesse ruth represse,
But if thou may with reason yet represse
Whose will her weakenesse could no way represse,
That womanish complaints she did represse,
Great warriours oft their rigour to represse,
And did the rigour of his doome represse;
And wrong repressed, and establisht right,
Him weening, ere he nigh approcht to haue represt.
Had not the noble Prince his readie stroke represt.
Vntill that Talus had his pride represt,
With wounding words and termes of foule repriefe
Then wound of gealous worme, and shame of such repriefe.
Least that it should her turne to foule repriefe,
Till that old Glauce gan with sharpe repriefe,
For misery craues rather mercie, then repriefe.
But if the least appear'd, her eyes she streight reprieued.
How that my Lord from her I would repriue,
It to repleuie, and my sonne repriue:
and doth from death repriue.
From th'earth, & from her wombe new spirits to reprize.
And proffer made by force her to reprize:
Colour thy name with foule reproaches rust.
And with reproch of carelesnesse vnkind
In fowle reproch of knighthoods faire degree,
In foule reproch, and termes of vile despight,
With whose reproch and odious menace
To chaunge loue causelesse is reproch to warlike knight.
And then due praise, or due reproch them yield;
For when Cymochles saw the fowle reproch,
Which when they saw, they weened fowle reproch
For thy, this hight The Rocke of vile Reproch,
But shame and sad reproch, here to be red,
To shunne Rocke of Reproch, and it as death to dred.
And afterwards they gan with fowle reproch
And sore reproch, when so her father deare
The worlds reproch, the cruell victors scorne,
Their brother to reproch and shamefull flight:
Me brought? ah farre be such reproch fro mee.
Spare, gentle sister, with reproch my paine to eeke.
Or else for shame, so fowle reproch to shonne,
Behinde him was Reproch, Repentance, Shame;
Reproch the first, Shame next, Repent behind:
Reproch despightfull, carelesse, and vnkind;
Shame lowrd, Repentance sigh'd, Reproch did scould;
Reproch sharpe stings, Repentance whips entwind,
The badges of reproch, he threw away,
And so great honour with so fowle reproch had blent.
And her late vile reproch, though vaunted vaine,
Then the reproch of pride and cruelnesse.
But he them spotted with reproch, or secrete shame.
I giuen haue, liue in reproch and scorne;
And him reuiled, and reproched sore
With foule reproches, and disdainfull spight
With sonnes owne blade, her fowle reproches spoke;
Slaunderous reproches, and fowle infamies,
And euery one threw forth reproches rife
These vile reproches gan vnto her speake;
And cursed heauen, and spake reprochfull shame
Which lewdnesse fild him with reprochfull paine
With fowle reprochfull words he boldly him defide.
What meanest thou by this reprochfull strife?
For that reprochfull fall right fowly he disdaynd.
And with reprochfull shame mine honour shent,
First her restraine from her reprochfull blame,
And with thy bloud abolish so reprochfull blot.
The whiles the Prince prickt with reprochfull shame,
For to reuenge that foule reprochfull shame,
Late foule dishonour and reprochfull spight,
And with vile curses, and reprochfull shame
And with reprochfull blasphemy defide,
Had stayned with reprochfull crueltie,
And with reprochfull words him thus bespake on hight;
For first it was to thee reprochfull blame,
That much he feared, least reprochfull blame
The which erewhile spake so reprochfully,
Which spake reprochfully, not caring where nor when.
Right sore agrieued at her sharpe reproofe,
Of that fowle euill, which all men reproue,
For who with reason can you aye reproue,
When she for ought him sharpely did reproue,
Of filthy wretch? well may shee you reproue
Then any should of falsenesse her reproue,
For thy, they ought not thing vnknowne reproue,
But often did my folly fowle reproue.
Their good, that none them rightly may reproue
Did him reproue, yet could him not restrayne,
Him of vngentle vsage did [re]proue
And shamefully reproued for his rudenesse fond.
With that, like one that hopelesse was repryu'd
With foule repulse from Fraunce was forced to retire.
And many bold repulse, and many hard
Shall backe repulse the valiaunt Brockwell twise,
Yet twise they were repulsed backe againe,
And much repynd, that both of victors meede,
Dame Vna, wearie Dame, and entrance did requere.
That roaring all with rage, did lowd requere
A bold defyance, did of him requere
And whatsoeuer else he would requere.
He would at her request prolong her nephews daies.
And you Sir knight, whose name mote I request,
They turne themselues, at Vnaes meeke request,
Faire Vna gan Fidelia faire request,
She was right ioyous of her iust request,
Discourst his voyage long, according his request.
Or rudely sdeigne a gentle harts request;
But he to shift their curious request,
Mote I request you tydings of my loue,
At whose request he gan him selfe aduise
So well that Leach did hearke to her request,
Was glad to yeeld vnto his good request:
But left his loue, albe her strong request,
Yet let me you of courtesie request,
By which he mote accomplish his request,
This their request the Captaine much appalled;
He him requested, as he was a knight,
And stablish termes betwixt both their requests,
But neede, that answers not to all requests,
That brothers hand shall dearely well requight
Who well them greeting, humbly did requight,
She suffred, yet at length she did requight,
What other meed then need me to requight,
And if none do, yet shame shal thee with shame requight.
When cause requird, but neuer out of time;
Whom she requir'd, that first fayre Amoret
Whom he requir'd his forward hast to stay,
Faire virgin (said the Prince) ye me require
By wise Fidelia? she doth thee require,
But death will neuer come, when needes require.
But marched to the strond, their passage to require.
After pursewing death once to require,
To weete, what they so rudely did require.
With hookes and ladles, as need did require;
About him day and night, which doe require,
The which to let you weet, will further time require.
Deceiu'd of gealous Iuno, did require
That nought but spoyle and vengeance did require.
So gan the rest him likewise to require,
The Lady to alight did eft require,
That passage money did of them require,
To all, that shall require my comfort in their smart.
I would thy selfe require thee to reueale,
Those were to weet (if that ye it require)
Was dead with feare, nathlesse as neede required,
For that the terme approching fast, required speed.
And shall find friends, if need requireth soe,
They lightly her requit (for small delight
Could scarse vphold; yet soone she it requit.
And what I cannot quite, requite with vsuree.
Which to requite, the Redcrosse knight him gaue
That shall Pyrrochles well requite, I wot,
What is your owne, that I mote you requite?
That first I may that wrong to him requite:
She would her selfe displease, so him requite.
Cast to requite, and with a slender dart,
Or curtesie with rudenesse to requite:
And offred him, his courtesie to requite,
And to requite him with the like againe,
And with his speare requited him againe,
Who them requites with court'sies seeming meet,
Striuing in vaine to rere him selfe vpright.
Whom she saluting faire, faire resaluted was.
So Marinell by him was rescu'd from his fone.
Vnto whose rescue forth rode Paridell;
To rescue Satyrane out of his pray;
And rescue him through succour of his might,
To rescue her, and daily meanes assay,
Yet rescue her thence by no meanes I may:
Gainst which no flight nor rescue mote auayle,
To rescue th'infant, ere he did him kill:
And then therein reseized was againe,
The false resemblance of Deceipt, I wist
And faire resemblance aboue all the rest,
In his diuine resemblance wondrous lyke:
The great Creatours owne resemblance bright,
That sate thereby, with gyantlike resemblance,
Their like resemblaunce much admired there,
Diuine resemblaunce, beauty soueraine rare,
She should aread; many resemblaunces
He did resemble to his Ladie bright;
The maker selfe resembling in her feature?
Therein resembling Ianus auncient,
Resembling God in his imperiall might;
For nothing he from her reseru'd apart,
She sought to saue, as thing reseru'd from stealth;
Reserue her cause to her eternall doome,
But rather will reserue it for a Canto new.
That we may vs reserue both fresh and strong,
And whom he list reserue, to be afflicted more.
In which her kingdomes throne is chiefly resiant.
So when he had resigned his regiment,
Whom when the Gyaunt saw, he soone resinde
Him booteth not resist, nor succour call,
Long time resist, gaue place to kindly rest,
Who when he saw it bootelesse to resist,
Encountring him with small resistance slew;
Immoueable, resistlesse, without end.
And their resistlesse rigour did eschew.
But Calidore with huge resistlesse might,
And commen to his reskew, ere his bitter bane.
As in their mistresse reskew, whom they lad;
With a strong gard, all reskew to preuent,
To reskew her from shamefull villany.
Vnto his reskew, and with earnest cry,
To reskew her from shame, and to reuenge her wrong.
Where, doubtfull which to take, her to reskew,
And slew him cruelly, ere any reskew came.
Vnto his reskew ran, and greedily him sped.
And without reskew led her quite away.
The louing couple need no reskew feare,
He gan deuise, how her he reskew mought,
T'employ her puissaunce to his reskew,
From which he lately had through reskew fled:
To reskew his owne Lord, but thought it iust t'obay.
And him rencountring fierce, reskewd the noble pray.
With heauenly powre, and by Angels reskewd,
Her selfe, well as I might, I reskewd tho,
Whom Arthur soone hath reskewed
And reskewed out of the heauy stownd.
Whom he had reskewed from captiuaunce
from Turpine reskewed is;
And lacke of reskewes will to parley driue;
Ne none there was to reskue her, ne none to baile.
